Rooster & Rice gives khao mun gai an SF flair, with an option to make it "Marina healthy" with skinless chicken breast and brown rice, or Paleo, chicken & veggie. I like the healthy customization, but if you want the true khao mun gai experience, you should try the Original option, with the poached/boiled chicken and the oh-so-delicious chicken fat rice. All orders also come with a ginger/garlic/spicy/sweet/soy sauce and a side of chicken broth, which you can drizzle on the chicken and rice to add more flavor. 

It's a tad expensive, especially for what is essentially street food in Asia, but it's definitely one of the best I've had outside of Singapore. The Marina location is bigger, while the SOMA location seems to be mostly a grab and go place.

excerpts: Not only is it 100x better than its predecessor (Urban Picnic, RIP), I was excited since I had been wanting to try the original location for ages (except for the fact that it's in the Marina
and I don't do the Marina).
and I both got The Original; I asked for all dark meat juicy chicken.
It was a cold day and the soup was a pleasant surprise.
The chicken itself was tasty and the soy sauce based sauce was amazing!
the original.author: Yi Z.
the original.review:
OMG OMG OMG, I almost fell out of my seat when I realized Rooster & Rice had opened up downstairs in my office building. Not only is it 100x better than its predecessor (Urban Picnic, RIP), I was excited since I had been wanting to try the original location for ages (except for the fact that it's in the Marina and I don't do the Marina).

For lunch, my date and I both got The Original; I asked for all dark meat juicy chicken. It was a cold day and the soup was a pleasant surprise. The chicken itself was tasty and the soy sauce based sauce was amazing! The rice was fantastic as well and had a good amount of chicken flavor.

The food is cooked authentically; only the price is not cheap. This is a great addition to the SOMA food scene and a wonderful complement to DragonEats nearby.

excerpts: I ordered the original: a very simple meal, basically just rice and chicken with a few cucumbers inside the box yet the sauce they provided definitely takes the meal to a new level.
I like spicy food
so I also added Habanero sauce to really get the flavor kicking.
Everything came together much better than I expected especially after looking at the pictures of the meals which are rather basic.
My only knock would be that it's a little more expensive than I expected, but I will definitely be going back.
the original.author: LeVar H.
the original.review: Went to grab a quick to go meal for lunch and was in and out within 10 minutes. I ordered the original: a very simple meal, basically just rice and chicken with a few cucumbers inside the box yet the sauce they provided definitely takes the meal to a new level. I like spicy food so I also added Habanero sauce to really get the flavor kicking. Everything came together much better than I expected especially after looking at the pictures of the meals which are rather basic. My only knock would be that it's a little more expensive than I expected, but I will definitely be going back.

excerpts: I got the Original, but there isn't much else choice on the menu (a good thing).
the original.author: Josh L.
the original.review: Straightforward, no-frills chicken and rice, delicious in its simplicity and high-quality ingredients. I got the Original, but there isn't much else choice on the menu (a good thing).

excerpts: I got the original which comes with their jasmine rice, chicken, some cucumbers and a side of broth for $12.
It's a bit pricey but the size is decent.
Just wish they had more included options instead of a la carte items like $2 for egg lol.
the original.author: Amanda K.
the original.review:
Busy during lunchtime with nearby yuppies but a good healthy/hearty alternative if you're not feeling a sandwich or salad. 

I got the original which comes with their jasmine rice, chicken, some cucumbers and a side of broth for $12. It's a bit pricey but the size is decent. Just wish they had more included options instead of a la carte items like $2 for egg lol. But all in all, everything tasted clean and the chicken was moist.

Not much table seating but plenty outside!

excerpts: The original's pretty good and filling, and the side order of fried chicken skin is delicious!
the original.author: Keith C.
the original.review:
Pretty decent meal for a reasonable price.  The food's fairly plain and simple, which I think is a good thing!  Just as the name implies, it's basically just chicken and rice, but you can add some toppings like an egg if you want.  The original's pretty good and filling, and the side order of fried chicken skin is delicious!  

My favorite part is probably how simple the whole thing is, definitely a nice and easy lunch outing during work.

excerpts: I got extra veggies (steamed broccoli), though the original portion was already more than enough for me.
the original.author: Jaclyn C.
the original.review:
Great addition to this east SoMa area with a general lack of Asian food options. The shop was not super spacious but had a few tables and could get very busy during weekday lunch hours. 

Simple menu with just four options, one vegetarian and three with chicken. Five of us got all different chicken options. "Paleo" option could be confusing - no rice and instead more veggies. I wanted to bring it up because their rice was the highlight of the meal for me! Chicken flavor was noticeable in the rice along with garlic and ginger, very tasty and just like in the classic Singapore style Hainan chicken. I got extra veggies (steamed broccoli), though the original portion was already more than enough for me. It also came with soup (tasty warm broth), perfect for a chilly day :)

A bit on the pricey side ($12+ for chicken options) that probably made me not go every time I ate out in the area, but certainly a place I'd crave once in a while.

excerpts: The Original:
Oddly, I liked everything about the dish except the actual chicken.
The rice was very rich and full of chicken flavor; I could probably eat mounds of this.
the original.author: Adam B.
the original.review:
This reminded me a little of Hainanese Chicken Rice, except with a side of chicken broth.  Pretty limited menu, so at least you know they specialize with their main dish.  It was worth trying, but it's not going to make it into my Top 20 favorite Thai dishes.

The Original:  Oddly, I liked everything about the dish except the actual chicken.  The rice was very rich and full of chicken flavor; I could probably eat mounds of this.  The chicken broth was more intense than typical chicken soup (maybe more fat content?) and did an excellent job at warming up the lukewarm chicken.  The soy-based sauce with ginger, garlic and chili added a ton of personality to the chicken and really was a treat if you dip the chicken in the broth first.  The cucumbers and cilantro help add a nice vegetal kick to cut through the richness of everything else.  The chicken though just wasn't my thing.  The limp boiled skin had such a weird slimy mouthfeel.  The chicken meat itself isn't that warm so it had the cooled off chicken taste.  And there were pieces of bone and cartilage in the mix.  In theory I'm not opposed to picking meat from the non-meat parts, but not in the middle of the workday when in nice business attire and surrounded by a bunch of professionals.  Pulling a piece of bone out of your mouth and putting it aside just seems so awkward.

excerpts: While that price tag will make me pause before going there, what I really didn't appreciate was that the marina (skinless chicken breast) cost more than the original which actually includes more meat (breast + thigh).
I didn't need or want the larger quantity of food, but I did want my chicken without skin.
I understand there is a small additional cost in the form of manual labor, but really?
It seemed like it was just "demand" pricing - they are expecting more people to order that so they priced it higher.
I guess if others feel like I do, the market won't bear it
and they'll have to change.
Or, the market will bear it, and good for their business.
the original.author: Sara E.
the original.review:
I'd say this place is really a 3.5 rather than a 3.  

Food - a solid 4 stars.  The menu is limited to a few main entrees, and their focus means these options are very high quality.  The ingredients are top notch and well-sourced (organic chicken etc).  The food, at first glance, looks relatively plain, but the chicken is cooked to tender perfection and once you add the sauce, your whole experience becomes layered w salty, spicy, fresh flavor.

Ambiance - 3.5 stars.  It has a clean, bright, light interior.  Not a ton of seating and most of it is communal, which I'm not a huge fan of.  I understand why they do it though - it is a more efficient use of space.  The seating area isn't as cramped as many SOMA restaurants, but it's not exactly sprawling either.

Value/price - 2 stars.  I understand they are using really high quality ingredients, and those ingredients cost money.  However, w tax and tip and no extras, this lunch was over $17 to go. While that price tag will make me pause before going there, what I really didn't appreciate was that the marina (skinless chicken breast) cost more than the original which actually includes more meat (breast + thigh).  I didn't need or want the larger quantity of food, but I did want my chicken without skin.  I understand there is a small additional cost in the form of manual labor, but really?  It seemed like it was just "demand" pricing - they are expecting more people to order that so they priced it higher.  I guess if others feel like I do, the market won't bear it and they'll have to change.  Or, the market will bear it, and good for their business.

excerpts: I got the original with an egg and a bottle of Thai tea.
My coworker got the original and an orange Fanta.
For the both of us, the total came out to be $37 and I thought that was pretty pricy...
I'm originally from LA
so I'm a bit biased because I've had better hainan chicken and rice.
the original.author: Amy L.
the original.review:
Tried this place for the first time and it was pretty good! I got the original with an egg and a bottle of Thai tea. My coworker got the original and an orange Fanta. For the both of us, the total came out to be $37 and I thought that was pretty pricy... I'm originally from LA so I'm a bit biased because I've had better hainan chicken and rice. The only unique part of this meal that differentiates the Thai style from the Chinese style is the dipping sauce.. and in my case I wouldn't mind having either one. 

We wen during lunchtime at around 1130am and beat the line. Chicken was tender, no bones, rice was flavorful and it also came with a cup of soup!

Overall, I was pretty satisfied with my meal and the portion sizes were also just right. I would probably come back and eat this again but not anytime soon.

excerpts: I wasn't even hungry, but got the original, and added an egg.
The check came out to close to $15.
You have to add an egg.
It was cooked perfectly!
That dipping sauce was soooooo good with the chicken and rice.
Everything was awesome.
I highly recommend trying this place out.
I'll definitely be back!
the original.author: Julia C.
the original.review: This place is amazing! I've been trying to make it here for the longest time and happened upon it on my way to the 24hr gym. I wasn't even hungry, but got the original, and added an egg. The check came out to close to $15.  You have to add an egg. It was cooked perfectly! That dipping sauce was soooooo good with the chicken and rice. Everything was awesome. I highly recommend trying this place out. I'll definitely be back!

excerpts: You can't go wrong with the original hunan chicken!
the original.author: Betty B.
the original.review: Rooster and rice is the perfect fast casual meal, the chicken broth is so good that I have to order two every time. You can't go wrong with the original hunan chicken!

excerpts: I ordered the original and the paleo Togo.
the original.author: Peter N.
the original.review:
I was craving Khao Man Gai in Portland and I found this little gem close to my work.  I ordered the original and the paleo Togo.  


The thigh meats were so soft, juicy and tender. The skin was just perfect--in my mouth. The broth was crisp, clean and enhances the flavour of the entire dish.  

It's one of my favourites. Super healthy.  Great tasting and very filling. If you're looking for a quick bite without the guilt of unhealthy calories this is your place.  If you're looking for something that comes close to home, this is your place.

excerpts: I got the original with an added egg because, duh.
The poached chicken was tender and delicious
, the rice tasted like it was cooked in chicken fat for 20 days because it was so tasty and the sauce was salty, sweet and brought everything together.
the original.author: Tina P.
the original.review: Simple and incredibly delicious is all you want when it comes to Asian chicken and rice and this place is both. I got the original with an added egg because, duh. The poached chicken was tender and delicious, the rice tasted like it was cooked in chicken fat for 20 days because it was so tasty and the sauce was salty, sweet and brought everything together. The broth was a good palette cleanser that was smooth and warm. Also, all their napkins, lids and bags have their signature chicken on them--so cute! Definitely coming back...everyday...for every meal.

excerpts: The Original and it comes with a mix of light and dark meat along with white rice (cooked in chicken broth).
Make sure to pour some of the herb-y soy sauce over the chicken to give it some flavor.
The portion size is alright.
I can finish it all without a problem and be full and satisfied but not overstuffed.
A guy with a bigger appetite might be a bit more unsatisfied.
If you need a little more food or want a more balanced meal, add some extra veggies.
The meal also comes with bone broth soup which is simple but tasty.
the original.author: Tiffany S.
the original.review:
Yay for khao mun gai aka Thai chicken rice aka hainan chicken (they all taste the same to me haha but maybe I just don't know any better)! Finally a place around the area that sells a decent version of this dish. It's not the best kind I've ever had but it'll happily satisfy my craving. Also a bit pricey for what it is but welcome to SF I guess.

I order The Original and it comes with a mix of light and dark meat along with white rice (cooked in chicken broth). Make sure to pour some of the herb-y soy sauce over the chicken to give it some flavor. The portion size is alright. I can finish it all without a problem and be full and satisfied but not overstuffed. A guy with a bigger appetite might be a bit more unsatisfied. If you need a little more food or want a more balanced meal, add some extra veggies. The meal also comes with bone broth soup which is simple but tasty. 

Good healthy choice for lunch/dinner! Wish it was closer to my office as I can only get it when I splurge for delivery.

excerpts: Get The Marina or The Paleo if you feel like something healthier, but for me it'll always be The Original!
the original.author: Carl W.
the original.review: It takes me 20 mins to walk here from where I live, and yet I've made it a habit to visit at least once every week, because it's just so worth it. No place in SF serves up a better Hainan Chicken. Get The Marina or The Paleo if you feel like something healthier, but for me it'll always be The Original!

excerpts: I didn't realize there was a difference in rice between the menu options, but I think I had the Original with regular white rice.
There's not much else to provide in a review, other than just bookmark and go try it sometime!

Counter service was quick and friendly, and after that you take care of your own sauces and utensils while waiting to pick up your compostable bowl of freshly-made and perfectly proportioned protein and carbs (and for some of you, veggies).
the original.author: Sherri C.
the original.review: Awesome!  Similar to Nong's in Portland -- and possibly even better.  Folks in SF are lucky to have a couple locations to choose from.  Rooster & Rice reminds me of yet another "food truck turned mini-shop" venture.  Seems many are taking advantage of the current order-take-out-and-sit-in phenomena.  My colleague and I enjoyed sitting outside on this particular day, though, as we were experiencing a break in the winter storms that have saturated the state.  I didn't realize there was a difference in rice between the menu options, but I think I had the Original with regular white rice.  There's not much else to provide in a review, other than just bookmark and go try it sometime!  Counter service was quick and friendly, and after that you take care of your own sauces and utensils while waiting to pick up your compostable bowl of freshly-made and perfectly proportioned protein and carbs (and for some of you, veggies).

excerpts: I got the original and the marina with extra breast meat for the bae.
the meat texture was chewy, just the right amount - what was amazing was the gingery soy sauce it came with the dish!
the original.author: holly n.
the original.review:
wow! just caviared my fiancé and my dinner for Wednesday night late dinner! I got the original and the marina with extra breast meat for the bae. the meat texture was chewy, just the right amount - what was amazing was the gingery soy sauce it came with the dish! can someone please share with me how I can make this at home?!?!  

so glad to have found this place! will def be a regular

excerpts: The one they provide is a mix between the original and bold, and it's pretty darn good.
You can buy a bottle of it as well.
the original.author: Jeannie L.
the original.review:
I've visited the Marina location and realize they opened one up near my work. YAY!

It's a simple dish, of thai chicken and rice. Think Chinese Hainan chicken but with different sauces, and fragrant rice. The difference maker is the hot sauce on the side, really makes it worth going to. The one they provide is a mix between the original and bold, and it's pretty darn good. You can buy a bottle of it as well. The dish also comes with a small cup of chicken broth and cilantro/green onion. Goes well with the dish. You can either pour it on or drink it solo. 

They had some fried chicken skin pieces to sample as well, and it was delicious. Anything fried is usually amazing. 

It's a little pricey, but in the FiDi, it's kind of expected. I can't remember if the prices were cheaper out in the Marina, but I feel like they would be. 

I'll be back!

excerpts: I had the Original.
the original.author: Stephanie C.
the original.review:
So good, I almost didn't write a review because I don't want more people coming and the line getting longer.

I had the Original. Chicken was juicy, broth is delicious.

excerpts: Anyhow, I got the original.
DUH.
the OG of course.
the original.author: Bonnie H.
the original.review:
Today is Trump's Inauguration day. So I needed something really good for lunch. Something that reminds me that life is worth living. 

I hopped on Yelp and saw that the Urban Picnic was replaced by Rooster & Rice, a place I had seen opened in the Marina, and now here it is - 2 blocks away from my work. Yay!

Upon arriving at Rooster & Rice, i see the line. I expected this as San Franciscans are crazy. I don't usually like lines. Some people go just for the line, it seems, but I stay away. This is the first time, I actually stood in the line. I dunno... maybe it's because today the world is ending. I mean if the US is going to try something new - like elect a fascist, xenophobic, racist, sexist imbecile, then I can also try something new. Like stand in a line.

Upon entry into the actual restaurant, I noticed that it was all asians and their more experimental non-asian friends. I don't know if I had ever seen so many asians in any other SOMA restaurant before. If Trump wanted to put all asians in an internment camp, they can make Rooster & Rice it's capital. He can just fence us all in like chickens.

Anyhow, I got the original. DUH. the OG of course. Jesus - the marina? Really? I'm not judging. I'm just saying... I'm judging.

Everything was pretty good and satisfying. As expected. The best thing was the broth which was super flavorful. Rice had a light flavor, which is fine. (Not as good as Hainanese chinese chicken, but it's fine.) Khao Mun Gai chicken is poached, where as Hainanese chicken is steamed - but end result is similar. Basically a very clean, chickeny flavor. 

This is why only the most experimental of non-asians would ever come here - that poached chicken. I think it's something you grow up with. To the non-asians, it's just rubbery and too chickeny. There's a reason why chicken is battered and fried. Or smothered with bbq sauce. I actually don't love chicken ...but there is something nostalgic about eating poached / steamed chicken. Very comforting. 

The ginger-soy sauce was of course delicious. You gotta have that right. I could talk about hainanese chicken sauce (which is a ginger scallion sauce), but I might have a gang of thai techies come beat me with a coconut hammer. 

(Aww.... don't get mad my Thai cousins... If it's any consolation, the Chinese don't do any noodle dishes as close to delicious as Tom Yum Noodle Soup.... mmmmm... Tom Yum Noodle Soup.)

Anyhow... seriously I'd say the only reason I am giving it 4 stars is because it's not Hainanese Chicken Rice. And I know that's not fair. But you know what... Today, a person who lost the popular vote by 2 million votes is being sworn into office. So life isn't fair. 

Maybe I'll update the review when life is fair again.

excerpts: I recommend ordering "The Original" and adding the sous vide egg to go with it.
The portions are very filling and the ginger/garlic sauce that comes with the meal is delicious.
the original.author: Lester W.
the original.review:
Glad to see that Rooster & Rice has opened up a location in the SoMa area.

I recommend ordering "The Original" and adding the sous vide egg to go with it. The portions are very filling and the ginger/garlic sauce that comes with the meal is delicious. The meal includes a chicken broth to help wash the meal down.

They have some seating inside and plenty of seating outside.

I'll definitely be adding this spot to my lunch rotation.

excerpts: I always get the original but with only dark meat.
The chicken is SO good and tender and has so much flavor.
The rice also has a lot of flavor and the combination of the chicken and rice is literally magical.
The sauce they provide is also so yummy and brings the rice/chicken to the next level.
the original.author: Stephanie W.
the original.review: This place is soooooo good. I wish it was just a LITTLE bit closer to where I live. I always get the original but with only dark meat. The chicken is SO good and tender and has so much flavor. The rice also has a lot of flavor and the combination of the chicken and rice is literally magical. The sauce they provide is also so yummy and brings the rice/chicken to the next level. The broth is also really good. YUMM. now i'm just craving rooster and rice.......

excerpts: I had the Original and felt no guilt.
the original.author: Fioni B.
the original.review: The food more than lived up to how good it looked on Yelp. so good in fact I wasn't even mad it was in a nondescript courtyard of an office building complex. As a tourist I was hoping for a hipper location . I was confused about what SOMA was. But I left satisfied and now I'm wishing they would open a location on Los Angeles' east side.   I like that there are limited option and each is healthier than the next. I had the Original and felt no guilt.

excerpts: wish i'd given the original location a try too
the original.author: Angie K.
the original.review:
you sf-ites have it good, man. burmese stops galore, $4 banh mi, andytown, and khao man gai? i hope u guys give thanks for all the goodness you have

anywho

when i saw that theres a place that does khao man gai i h a d to go. i chanced upon this dish for the first time a few month ago at nong's in portland (bless her soul) and i think its safe to say it kinda changed my life. dont sleep on khao man gai. "room temp chicken" sounds whack but when the sauce is right, such a simple, barebones dish can prove to be one of the most replenishing, fulfilling meals you could enjoy. 

and now reeling back from my philosophical divergence: i ordered the marina with extra vegetables and sauce.

it was ok! the sauce is pungent as it should be. it looked like there was some dried shrimp in the sauce alongside some pepper that added a much-needed kick. the chicken was most definitely not dry, despite it being skinless breast. the brown rice was cooked, all i could ask for. just barely the right amount for a proper chicken:rice ratio. the extra vegetables i got didn't seem to make it to my take-out container? or perhaps a few extra slices of cucumber were the extra vegetable, in which case, the +$2 was definitely not worth it.

regarding the broth, it was nice, but very single note. i expected radishes and some spring onion, additives that would make the broth crisp and refreshing as it had been at nong's. it sorta tasted like low-grade sushi miso soup with some chicken fat incorporated into the base.

eventually the marina + veggies + sauce (had to meet a minimum for the caviar order) rang up to be around $18 with the silly sf tax included. it was nice to fix the khao man gai craving, but not worth that heavy hit to the wallet.

really nice and clean store tho! wish i'd given the original location a try too

excerpts: I usually get their Marina with veggies and my husband gets the Original with egg.
Perfect meal on a chilly San Francisco day.
the original.author: Erica P.
the original.review: Rooster & Rice is SO delicious! I agree it's a bit pricey, but I'm willing to splurge every once in a while for a healthy, tasty and filling meal. I usually get their Marina with veggies and my husband gets the Original with egg. Perfect meal on a chilly San Francisco day.

excerpts: I always order the Original.
The chicken feels fresh, tender, and juicy.
The rice is super flavorful and most importantly... the sauce is just perfect.
the original.author: Andrew D.
the original.review: Kao mun gai is one of my favorite Thai dishes and I feel like it's not that common in SF. I've really only had it at the renowned Nong's in Portland. It's been a long time since I've been there so it's hard to compare but Rooster & Rice is certainly quite good. I always order the Original. The chicken feels fresh, tender, and juicy. The rice is super flavorful and most importantly... the sauce is just perfect. The chicken broth is also good.  The reason I'm dropping a star is because I don't think this meal is worth $13. Lunch is consistently less than $10 in the area so it's difficult to justify putting in the weekly lunch rotation. Adding an egg is $2 and a side of 6oz of fried chicken skin is $5. Pricey indeed.  But yeah, it's good. And you should totally try it.

excerpts: I had the original plate.
chicken was cooked perfectly and sauce was awesome.
only drawback.. the rice was a little grainy.
taste was great but texture let it down.
the original.author: Andy G.
the original.review:
Has a simple menu but great tasting food. great options like paleo and vegetarian(tofu).

I had the original plate.  chicken was cooked perfectly and sauce was awesome. only drawback.. the rice was a little grainy. taste was great but texture let it down.

excerpts: The Original.
Boring flavors.
They charged two dollars for six pieces of broccoli.
The sauce it came with was pretty good.
Decent amount of food.
the original.author: Kevin S.
the original.review: Order The Original. Boring flavors. They charged two dollars for six pieces of broccoli. The sauce it came with was pretty good. Decent amount of food.

excerpts: David started off by recommending his favorite - the original, and Eugene HIGHLY recommended me to add an egg.
My belly thanks them for it.
10/10 would come back again!
the original.author: Tony L.
the original.review: The service I received at Rooster and Rice from David and Eugene was exceptional. David started off by recommending his favorite - the original, and Eugene HIGHLY recommended me to add an egg. My belly thanks them for it. 10/10 would come back again!

excerpts: I ordered The Original near closing time on a Friday.
Having missed my lunch during normal hours, I was starving and found the first bite of the chicken to be gratifying.
The ginger sauce, the poached egg yolk, and the well-brined chicken breast with skin, topped with a few drips of habanero sauce, made for an amazing combination.
the original.author: Hank F.
the original.review: I ordered The Original near closing time on a Friday. Having missed my lunch during normal hours, I was starving and found the first bite of the chicken to be gratifying. The ginger sauce, the poached egg yolk, and the well-brined chicken breast with skin, topped with a few drips of habanero sauce, made for an amazing combination. Within 10 minutes, I had finished everything and washed down the food with the chicken broth, leaving me feeling very happy about the meal.

excerpts: I got the original, but next time I think I'll try the paleo as there was a LOT of rice in the original.
It's not cheap but the portions are huge and it can easily be split between two.
It would be great if they offered a half order.
the original.author: El B.
the original.review: Yup. It's good. I got the original, but next time I think I'll try the paleo as there was a LOT of rice in the original. It's not cheap but the portions are huge and it can easily be split between two. It would be great if they offered a half order.

excerpts: the original with extra cucumbers.
The line is out the door and the space is packed with people waiting for their order.
The flavors of the sauce was amazing.
Wish I had more of it though.
the original.author: Mello M.
the original.review: Was recommend by a co-worker.  I liked my lunch today, the original with extra cucumbers.  The line is out the door and the space is packed with people waiting for their order.  The flavors of the sauce was amazing.  Wish I had more of it though.

excerpts: You can choose between 4 variations, "The Original" has breast & thigh w/skin, jasmine white rice, "The Marina" has skinless breast, organic brown rice, "The Vegetarian" had organic tofu, brown rice and seasonal veggies and "The Paleo
" has breast/thigh and seasonal veggies.
the marina.author: Chelsea W.
the marina.review:
Rooster & Rice is really overhyped and I'm surprised there are so many good ratings. The chicken and rice itself are pretty ordinary, and the sauce is really the only good part of the dish.

Given the there's a new location in SoMa, I decided to give it another try, but it was just as plain and ordinary as I remembered. You can choose between 4 variations, "The Original" has breast & thigh w/skin, jasmine white rice, "The Marina" has skinless breast, organic brown rice, "The Vegetarian" had organic tofu, brown rice and seasonal veggies and "The Paleo" has breast/thigh and seasonal veggies. It comes out to about $14 which is pretty overpriced in my opinion. 

I had the "Paleo" and it was so-so. The seasonal veggies are always steamed broccoli, so it really doesn't stand out to me too much. I imagine that its a popular place since its a healthier option in the area.

excerpts: There's more seating here than in the Marina, about a dozen seats inside, several patio tables on the immediate terrace and lots of open seating in the 303 2nd Street plaza, an inviting spot on a warm day akin to the wooden lounges on The High Line (photo: http://bit.ly/2eMabt0).

I've been making a culturally insensitive remark by referring to the specialty here as Hainan chicken, the Singaporean dish which is what I am most familiar with from its best stateside version at the Savoy Kitchen down in Alhambra
(review: http://bit.ly/2uWbMTL).
the marina.author: Ed U.
the marina.review:
Ever since Bryan Lew and Tommy Charoen opened up their Marina shop (review: http://bit.ly/2uXGQ5b), I was hoping they would open another shop closer to my neighborhood in SoMa. After all, I can never get enough steamed chicken, or in this case, poached Thai-style. There's only four items on the menu. The $11.95 Original is their most popular item and the classic version of Khao Mun Gai, a breast and a thigh, both sliced boneless with their skin left intact, accompanied by some jasmine white rice that got intimate with the cup of chicken broth that comes with the dish. The $12.95 Marina is aptly named because it's a skinless breast with brown rice.

That sounds so Marina. You can bypass the cluck entirely by ordering the $9.95 Vegetarian with tofu, brown rice and seasonal vegetables, or you can split the difference like what me and Jamie W. did and order the $12.95 Paleo which allows you the choice between a breast or a thigh and accompanied just by the seasonal vegetables with no rice. While we love broth-drenched rice, we didn't need the extra calories or barbs, and the chicken was nicely succulent (photo: http://bit.ly/2eMp3Yg). I barely used the spicy soy sauce preferring instead the chili-infused hot sauce they provide in squeeze bottles. It has a real kick which goes well with the broccoli.

By the way, broccoli is the only "seasonal vegetable" I've ever seen them serve so keep that in mind. There's more seating here than in the Marina, about a dozen seats inside, several patio tables on the immediate terrace and lots of open seating in the 303 2nd Street plaza, an inviting spot on a warm day akin to the wooden lounges on The High Line (photo: http://bit.ly/2eMabt0). I've been making a culturally insensitive remark by referring to the specialty here as Hainan chicken, the Singaporean dish which is what I am most familiar with from its best stateside version at the Savoy Kitchen down in Alhambra (review: http://bit.ly/2uWbMTL). But hell, this was pretty damn good, too.

FOOD - 4 stars...Thai-style poached chicken is a tasty delight for those looking for a Hainan chicken fix like me
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...small, clean and modern with a distinct lack of character and a primarily Asian target market...none of the Giants fans appear to stop here on the way to the game
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...OK, nothing special...though I like how they stay open until 8PM on weekdays for those of who don't work in the area...wish they'd stay open on the weekends
TOTAL - 4 stars...paleo is the way to go at this fast cluck stop

excerpts: I decided to go with The Marina because I'm still on a low calorie diet and this was nutritious enough for me to not have to worry about it turning into fat.
the marina.author: Tim G.
the marina.review:
I took a break from my MealPal adventures and met up with a friend for lunch at Rooster & Rice. After reading the reviews, I decided we should probably head here before noon in order to beat the lunch time rush. We arrived at 11:45am and there was already a line forming out the door. 

The lunch line moves pretty quickly and they have already perfected the ordering process. I decided to go with The Marina because I'm still on a low calorie diet and this was nutritious enough for me to not have to worry about it turning into fat. It's all white meat chicken with veggies, brown rice, sauce, and a cup of broth. Now granted this was a $15 lunch, it's not cheap. I do feel like the ingredients are high quality and organic does give me the warm and fuzzies. 

Getting a table wasn't too difficult. Two seats freed up on the communal table by the time we got to the front of the line if you don't mind eating a strangers. Otherwise there's outdoor seating but it was a little too chilly outside for that. 

It would be great if they participate in MealPal though. I'd eat it daily.

excerpts: I got the Marina (#2) and boy was it delicious!
Takes me back to eating at street carts in Thailand!
the marina.author: Andrea O.
the marina.review: A teammate recently introduced me to Rooster & Rice, which was a dangerous move. I got the Marina (#2) and boy was it delicious! Takes me back to eating at street carts in Thailand! The chicken was tender and moist, brown rice seasoned extremely well (thinking that they might use the broth to make it), delicious sauce, and the broth was seasoned perfectly! A healthy lunch option that's delicious, and it lasted me two meals. Will def be here again, especially once the weather cools down.

excerpts: Ordered "The Marina", skinless chicken breast with brown rice.
Service is fast, the food comes in compact form but portions aren't big enough in my opinion.
The taste was ok, a bit spicy tho.
Also their napkins are surprisingly soft and thick.
the marina.author: Rafic K.
the marina.review: Ordered "The Marina", skinless chicken breast with brown rice. Service is fast, the food comes in compact form but portions aren't big enough in my opinion. The taste was ok, a bit spicy tho. Also their napkins are surprisingly soft and thick.

excerpts: The Marina is "healthier" since it's skinless chicken with brown rice.
The Paleo was good as well
but it's just chicken and veggie.
the marina.author: Peter L.
the marina.review:
I would go here for the ginger soy sauce dip and the cooked rice - they probably cook the rice in chicken broth instead of water - because both were so good!

Of the four options the Original was my favorite. It's a basic boiled chicken with warm rice comfort food. The Marina is "healthier" since it's skinless chicken with brown rice. The Paleo was good as well but it's just chicken and veggie. All orders come with a cup of chicken broth.

You can add a soft egg to each order but it's not needed unless you really want a runny egg with your meal. They have a dipping Sriracha sauce blend if you want a kick.

Go around 12:45pm or later and avoid the lunch crowd line. Be prepared to wait after ordering though.

excerpts: I ordered "The Marina" which is brown rice, skinless chicken breast and cucumbers.
I added some extra vegetables (broccoli in my case) and man was it delicious!
the marina.author: Benjamin F.
the marina.review:
This place. Is. Nails. 

If you're looking for a healthy, flavorful option in SOMA then Rooster & Rice is a fantastic option. Be prepared to wait in a little bit of a line during lunch hours but, it moves quick enough and is well worth the wait. 

I ordered "The Marina" which is brown rice, skinless chicken breast and cucumbers. I added some extra vegetables (broccoli in my case) and man was it delicious! It comes with a great soy based sauce that's chalk full of onions, garlic and other flavor filled herbs. 

Get here ASAP. Out.

excerpts: I ordered "The Marina" chicken plate which it includes skinless, poached organic Mary's chicken breast with organic brown rice and slices of fresh cucumbers.
the marina.author: William L.
the marina.review:
On 8/1/2017, I decided to try this chicken food shop located within the 303 2nd Street building in South Market neighborhood called, "Rooster & Rice." Rooster & Rice serves the customers to taste their finest "Khao Mun Gai" entrees that will devour their tastebuds! The atmosphere and the concept is much simple by serving one of Thai's greatest and easiest food to go option by adding chicken and rice combined especially for vegans too which they also have organic tofu with rice as an alternative!

The employees from counters and cookers are doing a great job for making the customers like me a tremendous service! Friendly and approachable. No cons at all!

Now onto the food! I ordered "The Marina" chicken plate which it includes skinless, poached organic Mary's chicken breast with organic brown rice and slices of fresh cucumbers. It also includes fresh chili ginger garlic with soybeans sauce and a small cup size of fresh chicken broth. As a result, that meal tasted flawless and outstanding! It compared and tasted like eating a Chinese styled chicken breast right directly from an Asian supermarket because of a distinct broth taste! Very clean and eatable to bite without any leftover bones around! The brown rice also cooked perfectly without being too harden and dry especially the sliced cucumbers. The sauce, da bomb goodness! I really tasted the ginger into my mouth along with a spicier taste of chili and garlic combined! Awesome sauce! Finally, the chicken broth tasted superior and naturally delicious just like slurping Sawnson's Chicken Broth. Not a bad meal for lunch!

Parking at Rooster & Rice can be quite challenging to park. You can park at the nearby surface metered street parking if it's available. Alternatively, you can also ride a bike, walk, carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

In the end, Rooster & Rice is the finest and most remarkable chicken food shop that I've ever visited for the very first time right here in San Francisco! Perfect for your lunch or dinner break needs! A well visit! My rating: 4 solid stars.

excerpts: I had actually been thinking (read: dreaming) about the Marina location of Rooster & Rice recently and wanted to go back.
One day while running errands in SoMa, I Yelped a place for lunch and discovered that Rooster & Rice opened up another location nearby!
Jackpot!!
I'm never in the Marina, so this SoMa location is quite a blessing.
There's plenty of seating outside in the plaza.
On a sunny San Francisco day, the greenery and fountain are gorgeous.
There's also some seating inside -- more than the Marina location -- but I prefer sitting outdoors while enjoying this warm and cozy meal.
the marina.author: Stefanie C.
the marina.review:
I had actually been thinking (read: dreaming) about the Marina location of Rooster & Rice recently and wanted to go back. One day while running errands in SoMa, I Yelped a place for lunch and discovered that Rooster & Rice opened up another location nearby! Jackpot!! It was in the middle of the lunch rush, but I think enough people are unaware of the awesomeness that is Rooster & Rice, so it wasn't too much of a wait. 

Of course, I got the Khao Mun Gai "The Original" which is soooo delicious. Love how limited this menu is. They specialize in just a few things, and you can add a few extras on top of whatever you order. Each dish comes with a small bowl of chicken soup. Hot, fresh, and tasty. The chicken and rice comes with a side of garlic and ginger sauce, which is the perfect degree of seasoning. You can also drench everything with the hot sauce available. Gives it a nice kick. 

Rooster & Rice is one of my favorite lunch spots in the city. I'm never in the Marina, so this SoMa location is quite a blessing. There's plenty of seating outside in the plaza. On a sunny San Francisco day, the greenery and fountain are gorgeous. There's also some seating inside -- more than the Marina location -- but I prefer sitting outdoors while enjoying this warm and cozy meal.

excerpts: I ordered the marina with extra chicken for lunch.
I also got an egg for $2 and that was very disappointing.
It was sloppily done, kind of runny but not really.
the marina.author: Alex S.
the marina.review:
I ordered the marina with extra chicken for lunch. I also got an egg for $2 and that was very disappointing. It was sloppily done, kind of runny but not really. Everything else was fantastic, reminiscent of hainan chicken and rice. 

The wait for not too long, about 10 minutes in liken and another 10 minutes for food. They also had a Thai sriracha sauce, and a habanero sauce. However I'd say the sauce provided with the lunch box went along much better than the sriracha and habanero. 

The location has a lot of sunshine, is close by to a fountain with plenty of open space where lots of people come to enjoy their meal. It was a pleasant experience with delicious food. Just wish the egg was done better!

excerpts: The Marina is my staple dish.
Good portion of tender chicken breast sliced up over brown rice.
the marina.author: John M.
the marina.review:
I was hit with a great smell upon entering this place.  The concept and food is pretty simple.  The Marina is my staple dish.  Good portion of tender chicken breast sliced up over brown rice.  I love the little broth they give you.

I don't think $13 bucks for lunch is crazy at all.  I hear from random people how this place is kind of expensive.  I don't get it.  If the food tastes fresh and healthy, then expect to weigh that into the price.

This place is kind of far for me but a worthy lunch spot for meal rotation.

excerpts: I've been to the Marina location and liked it a lot, so was very glad there's now a location close to me.
Came on a Monday night around 6, and waited over thirty minutes for my food after ordering.
I was pretty mad, but we received a sincere apology, got an explanation for why the food was late, and was offered free drinks when we finally got our food.
the marina.author: Julie Z.
the marina.review:
I've been to the Marina location and liked it a lot, so was very glad there's now a location close to me. Came on a Monday night around 6, and waited over thirty minutes for my food after ordering. I was pretty mad, but we received a sincere apology, got an explanation for why the food was late, and was offered free drinks when we finally got our food. I think most of the time when people are pissed off about bad service, they really just want an apology and explanation. 

In terms of food, I thought the chicken was just slightly dry, but the sauce totally makes up for it though. It's got a tinge of sweetness and not all oil like some of the other places, and I only wish there was more of it. The rice is super soft and not too greasy, and definitely try both hot sauces!

excerpts: I usually get the Marina -- breast, skinless over brown rice -- and it's amazing!
the marina.author: Genevieve M.
the marina.review:
Tucked away in the corner of the plaza of 303 2nd Street, Rooster & Rice is a booming new craze in the South of Market area of San Francisco. During lunch hours the line is straight out the door, but this is expected as SoMa is chock-full of busy, urban professionals. Clean and modern feel on the inside. You order at the cashier and wait for your name to be called, and you can either grab a seat at a table/bartop or take it to-go.

Menu doesn't seem diverse, but each chicken-over-rice (or vegetables) combo has its own unique flair. I usually get the Marina -- breast, skinless over brown rice -- and it's amazing! Love the broth on the side, too. I was in there for days at a time when I went to work sick (-: They provide a garlic soybean sauce with the order, but you can also add this orange hot sauce on the side. The meal is super light and I don't hate myself afterwards. A weekly ritual!

excerpts: The original bowl come with chicken & white jasmine rice, the Marina comes with brown, and there is also a vegetarian option that subs the chicken with organic tofu.
You can also do add ons for a few dollars more, such as adding an egg.
It's a great healthy lunch option or even post-workout meal.
Over all it's a bit pricey for a meal, but the quality and portion sizes are worth it.
the marina.author: Joy W.
the marina.review:
As the name suggests, the specialities of this place are chicken & rice.

I got the Paleo Bowl which came with chicken, seasonal veggies (broccoli when I went), cucumbers, and a cup of chicken broth. I got a mix of thigh & breast meat, and my it was so unbelievably tender. The chicken flavorful and super juicy. The price is a bit steep since it was $12.95 and after tax, about $14. However, they use organic Mary's chicken and the chicken was indeed a enormous portion. The broth was super flavorful and tasted like the kind of broth my mom would stew with chicken bones and make me drink when I was sick as a kid. Definitely use the ginger garlic soybean dipping sauce that comes with it too!

The original bowl come with chicken & white jasmine rice, the Marina comes with brown, and there is also a vegetarian option that subs the chicken with organic tofu. You can also do add ons for a few dollars more, such as adding an egg. It's a great healthy lunch option or even post-workout meal. Over all it's a bit pricey for a meal, but the quality and portion sizes are worth it.

excerpts: Simple, but somewhat time-consuming to make, Rooster & Rice finally brought what it had to offer to SoMa, after a successful start in the Marina.
the marina.author: Johnny W.
the marina.review:
*** In Short ***

Tasty and accessible Thai chicken rice in an area all-too-lacking in Asian food.

*** In Depth ***

If you've never had khao man gai, it's the Thai take on Hainan chicken rice: similar in preparation, but with a slightly different flavor profile. Simple, but somewhat time-consuming to make, Rooster & Rice finally brought what it had to offer to SoMa, after a successful start in the Marina. And thank god they did, because this part of town has always been a bit lacking in solid Asian eats!

There's not much else to say here other than that they've done a great job capturing both the flavor and simplicity of this comfort food, serving up tender and moist chicken, with an equally flavorful side of chicken broth to pair. Of course, expect the typical SF tax on what is traditionally a pretty cheap eat, but hey, that comes with the territory, right?

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A smaller shop with plenty of seating in the courtyard outside, the only real accessibility issue you might face here is reaching their hot sauces, which are usually on a pretty high shelf above another counter. That, and carrying about your soup without spilling it.

Bathroom - Didn't try them.

excerpts: Same great chicken as the Marina location, with significantly worse service.
The cashier and a person in the back were looking at Tinder profiles together when I showed up, and it took a solid minute for them to disengage.
As I was eating, I noticed that they took their Tinder swiping to the back, even though there were people waiting to be served.
Great chicken, but don't expect a friendly experience.
the marina.author: Christina S.
the marina.review: Same great chicken as the Marina location, with significantly worse service. The cashier and a person in the back were looking at Tinder profiles together when I showed up, and it took a solid minute for them to disengage. As I was eating, I noticed that they took their Tinder swiping to the back, even though there were people waiting to be served. Great chicken, but don't expect a friendly experience.

excerpts: I got The Marina which comes with skinless chicken breast & brown rice.
Sauce was good, went well with the chicken & rice which were also very good.
the marina.author: Kelley P.
the marina.review:
Simple and straight forward. Wanted more cucumbers/veggies with my order, but will keep that in mind for next time (guess I'll have to ask for extra?). I got The Marina which comes with skinless chicken breast & brown rice. Sauce was good, went well with the chicken & rice which were also very good. Broth also good. Great customer service. Quick and easy pick up after my workout nearby.

Other:
They don't have Apple Pay, despite what the info says.

excerpts: I mean this place cleary wants you to be sickened by their original so they can price gouge you on the Marina "healthy" option for 2 dollars more!
I posted a photo of what I believe is chicken skin on this yelp review.
That is all I am going to rant for now but never going back after my experience here.
the marina.author: Kazmo V.
the marina.review:
BUYER BEWARE!!! 

Just bought an "original" chicken and rice bowl from this hole in the wall and was shocked with what I found! My bowl consisted of about 70% chicken skin and fat and 30% meat which is unreal for a $12 lunch IMO. I mean this place cleary wants you to be sickened by their original so they can price gouge you on the Marina "healthy" option for 2 dollars more! I posted a photo of what I believe is chicken skin on this yelp review. That is all I am going to rant for now but never going back after my experience here.

excerpts: Order the original with white rice, the marina with brown rice, the paleo with seasonal veggies in lieu of rice or the vegetarian, tofu in lieu of that chicken.
the marina.author: Stephanie Y.
the marina.review:
The lines will be long, but it goes by fast and it's worth it, yo!

You will be spending about $15+ on lunch though, no doubt. But that lunch will be filled with juicy, healthy chicken on a bed of delicious rice served with a little cup of bone broth. Healthy, filling and oh so satisfying. What gets ya is the additional add-on's, pricewise. Want extra veggies? $3. Want an egg? $3. Goodbye are the days of cheap eats for lunch.

Order the original with white rice, the marina with brown rice, the paleo with seasonal veggies in lieu of rice or the vegetarian, tofu in lieu of that chicken.

They have a tasty soy based sauce to pour on and don't forget your little cups of sriracha or what looks to be housemade habanero. If you're gonna drop $15+ on lunch, this is a great option.

Plenty of outside seating both with tables and chairs, but also some funky seating in the courtyard; perfect for a sunny San Francisco day.

excerpts: Second best option is the The Marina if you don't want to stab yourself potentially with bones.
Chicken, however, is aces either way.
the marina.author: Anthony N.
the marina.review:
It took me a while to figure this place out, so let me break it down for you.

You need to get the ​The Original. It's dope. And you know it's real chicken because sometimes the thighs still have sharp ass bones in them. Second best option is the The Marina if you don't want to stab yourself potentially with bones. Chicken, however, is aces either way. You cannot go wrong with chicken at a place called Rooster & Rice.

What you need to do is request the addition of veggies. It's extra. I do not understand why their main dish doesn't come with a single piece of veggie (which happened the first time I ordered here), but you need something to balance all that dry ass rice and delicious sauce. 

Once everything's done, you'll quickly realize it's almost too much food for one sitting. My tip, carve out the section that you want to eat and plan to save it for another late night meal.

That way, your overpriced $17 San Francisco lunch won't feel like robbery. Although it is, don't kid yourself.

excerpts: The menu is short, featuring only a few variants of chicken rice with clever names like "The Marina" -- a healthier skinless chicken option over brown rice.
the marina.author: Brittany C.
the marina.review:
As everyone seems to agree, this place is a solid four stars. Great place to get a filling and (relatively) healthy meal in downtown. Rooster & Rice serves a Thai variation of Hainanese chicken rice, which features juicy, tender chicken over rice, combined with a very flavorful soy-based sauce. The portion size is generous and will leave you feeling satisfied. It also comes with chicken broth on the side, which is lightly flavored and comforting.

The menu is short, featuring only a few variants of chicken rice with clever names like "The Marina" -- a healthier skinless chicken option over brown rice. As a result, the line moves quickly, so don't be intimidated by what looks like a long wait.

Docking a star because it's so pricy, but I'll probably still make my way over every now and then, because the chicken rice really is that good.

excerpts: Finally got to try Rooster & Rice after having the Marina location bookmarked for months, and I was not disappointed!
Came here with my friends one rainy day for lunch
and it was completely packed
- we ended up taking our food to go because there was nowhere to sit.
the marina.author: KC W.
the marina.review:
Finally got to try Rooster & Rice after having the Marina location bookmarked for months, and I was not disappointed! Came here with my friends one rainy day for lunch and it was completely packed - we ended up taking our food to go because there was nowhere to sit. We all had the original, chicken breast and thigh with skin over jasmine rice, which also comes with a small bowl of delicious soup. The chicken itself was incredibly tender and flavorful, and even better with the ginger sauce that comes with it (even though I had to pick out all the leaves of cilantro). There are also two more sauces you can serve yourself, but the spicy orange one is better than the red tangy one. 

The price was pretty reasonable especially considering portion size because I was quite full after devouring the entire box. I just wish they had a bigger space with more seating, but there are many public spaces in the area where you can take your food to go. Though the menu is very simple, the quality of food is top notch and well worth the wait. Definitely will be back in the future to satisfy my Hainan chicken cravings!

excerpts: My boyfriend ordered The Marina because he doesn't like when chicken is fatty or has skin, but I actually think that he would've been just as happy with The Original.
the marina.author: Sara L.
the marina.review:
Thought that the khao mun gai here was a homey, comforting, and satisfying meal. 

I ordered The Original for myself. The chicken in the bowl was lean yet very tender and flavorful. My boyfriend ordered The Marina because he doesn't like when chicken is fatty or has skin, but I actually think that he would've been just as happy with The Original. The chicken in The Original (even the thigh) was just as lean, and I actually didn't get any skin in my bowl. That last part might be a big negative to some, but I didn't mind much. The broth was good too. Full of flavor, and not heavy or oily.

The jasmine rice was like the rice that's usually included in Hainan chicken dishes, in that it was very flavorful on its own. For that reason, don't dump the whole sauce container over the rice! The sauce is SUPER delicious, but if you put too much into the bowl, it can overpower the flavors of the chicken and the rice. Same goes for the optional Thai sriracha and the habanero sauce that they offer. SO good, but be careful how much you use because the bowl is far from bland even without them. 

Would this be 5 stars if this was cheaper? Definitely. In fact, I have no doubt that the same dish could be as little as half the price in Thai restaurants located elsewhere, like LA or Thailand itself. But let's be real: This is San Francisco. This is where many people don't think twice about dropping $15 for a simple salad. So Rooster & Rice isn't cheap, but I wouldn't say it's overpriced.

With that said, I really enjoyed the food here, and I'm happy that they opened this SoMa location.

excerpts: I had the Original and the Marina.
Marina has brown rice and no skin on the chicken .
The original has white rice and skin on some pieces of the chicken.
I always call in so I can stand in line versus ordering there.
the marina.author: Stephanie C.
the marina.review: My girlfriend told me about this location.  This is my second time and now I know how to order.  I had the Original and the Marina.  Marina has brown rice and no skin on the chicken .  The original has white rice and skin on some pieces of the chicken.  I always call in so I can stand in line versus ordering there.  I love their broth as there is no MSG in it.  I wish there were more veggies with the meal.  Thank is why I am giving a 4 star.

excerpts: The Marina location is bigger, while the SOMA location seems to be mostly a grab and go place.
the marina.author: Kate M.
the marina.review:
Finally, a decent place to get khao mun gai in SF! Kao mun gai, or the Thai verson ofHainan chicken rice, is one of the most popular street food in Singapore, and despite its extremely simple premise, is super flavorful. The secret is the super flavorful rice, flavored with chicken broth, chicken fat, oil, and whatever sauce you include, such as garlic. 

Rooster & Rice gives khao mun gai an SF flair, with an option to make it "Marina healthy" with skinless chicken breast and brown rice, or Paleo, chicken & veggie. I like the healthy customization, but if you want the true khao mun gai experience, you should try the Original option, with the poached/boiled chicken and the oh-so-delicious chicken fat rice. All orders also come with a ginger/garlic/spicy/sweet/soy sauce and a side of chicken broth, which you can drizzle on the chicken and rice to add more flavor. 

It's a tad expensive, especially for what is essentially street food in Asia, but it's definitely one of the best I've had outside of Singapore. The Marina location is bigger, while the SOMA location seems to be mostly a grab and go place.

excerpts: Not only is it 100x better than its predecessor (Urban Picnic, RIP), I was excited since I had been wanting to try the original location for ages (except for the fact that it's in the Marina
and I don't do the Marina).
and I both got The Original; I asked for all dark meat juicy chicken.
It was a cold day and the soup was a pleasant surprise.
The chicken itself was tasty and the soy sauce based sauce was amazing!
the marina.author: Yi Z.
the marina.review:
OMG OMG OMG, I almost fell out of my seat when I realized Rooster & Rice had opened up downstairs in my office building. Not only is it 100x better than its predecessor (Urban Picnic, RIP), I was excited since I had been wanting to try the original location for ages (except for the fact that it's in the Marina and I don't do the Marina).

For lunch, my date and I both got The Original; I asked for all dark meat juicy chicken. It was a cold day and the soup was a pleasant surprise. The chicken itself was tasty and the soy sauce based sauce was amazing! The rice was fantastic as well and had a good amount of chicken flavor.

The food is cooked authentically; only the price is not cheap. This is a great addition to the SOMA food scene and a wonderful complement to DragonEats nearby.

excerpts: While that price tag will make me pause before going there, what I really didn't appreciate was that the marina (skinless chicken breast) cost more than the original which actually includes more meat (breast + thigh).
I didn't need or want the larger quantity of food, but I did want my chicken without skin.
I understand there is a small additional cost in the form of manual labor, but really?
It seemed like it was just "demand" pricing - they are expecting more people to order that so they priced it higher.
I guess if others feel like I do, the market won't bear it
and they'll have to change.
Or, the market will bear it, and good for their business.
the marina.author: Sara E.
the marina.review:
I'd say this place is really a 3.5 rather than a 3.  

Food - a solid 4 stars.  The menu is limited to a few main entrees, and their focus means these options are very high quality.  The ingredients are top notch and well-sourced (organic chicken etc).  The food, at first glance, looks relatively plain, but the chicken is cooked to tender perfection and once you add the sauce, your whole experience becomes layered w salty, spicy, fresh flavor.

Ambiance - 3.5 stars.  It has a clean, bright, light interior.  Not a ton of seating and most of it is communal, which I'm not a huge fan of.  I understand why they do it though - it is a more efficient use of space.  The seating area isn't as cramped as many SOMA restaurants, but it's not exactly sprawling either.

Value/price - 2 stars.  I understand they are using really high quality ingredients, and those ingredients cost money.  However, w tax and tip and no extras, this lunch was over $17 to go. While that price tag will make me pause before going there, what I really didn't appreciate was that the marina (skinless chicken breast) cost more than the original which actually includes more meat (breast + thigh).  I didn't need or want the larger quantity of food, but I did want my chicken without skin.  I understand there is a small additional cost in the form of manual labor, but really?  It seemed like it was just "demand" pricing - they are expecting more people to order that so they priced it higher.  I guess if others feel like I do, the market won't bear it and they'll have to change.  Or, the market will bear it, and good for their business.

excerpts: I have  had the Marina location booked forever to try since thy opened.
However, over the weekend I saw this sign go up by mi casa.
They took over the old Urban Picnic and its refreshing.
They add a different line up to the food scene in SOMA for lunch.
Still the same simple 4 item menu but yet so delish.
I got the Paleo with breast and a poached egg.
A little price at almost $20 for chicken, broccoli, and an egg
but it was clean and healthy.
the marina.author: Tao Tao W.
the marina.review:
4.5 stars for sure. they had their soft opening today. I have  had the Marina location booked forever to try since thy opened. However, over the weekend I saw this sign go up by mi casa. They took over the old Urban Picnic and its refreshing. They add a different line up to the food scene in SOMA for lunch. Still the same simple 4 item menu but yet so delish. I got the Paleo with breast and a poached egg. A little price at almost $20 for chicken, broccoli, and an egg but it was clean and healthy. It came with broth too which props to them of it not tasting like oil water. 

will def be back.

excerpts: Get The Marina or The Paleo if you feel like something healthier, but for me it'll always be The Original!
the marina.author: Carl W.
the marina.review: It takes me 20 mins to walk here from where I live, and yet I've made it a habit to visit at least once every week, because it's just so worth it. No place in SF serves up a better Hainan Chicken. Get The Marina or The Paleo if you feel like something healthier, but for me it'll always be The Original!

excerpts: I got the original and the marina with extra breast meat for the bae.
the meat texture was chewy, just the right amount - what was amazing was the gingery soy sauce it came with the dish!
the marina.author: holly n.
the marina.review:
wow! just caviared my fiancé and my dinner for Wednesday night late dinner! I got the original and the marina with extra breast meat for the bae. the meat texture was chewy, just the right amount - what was amazing was the gingery soy sauce it came with the dish! can someone please share with me how I can make this at home?!?!  

so glad to have found this place! will def be a regular

excerpts: I've visited the Marina location and realize they opened one up near my work.
I can't remember if the prices were cheaper out in the Marina, but I feel like they would be.
the marina.author: Jeannie L.
the marina.review:
I've visited the Marina location and realize they opened one up near my work. YAY!

It's a simple dish, of thai chicken and rice. Think Chinese Hainan chicken but with different sauces, and fragrant rice. The difference maker is the hot sauce on the side, really makes it worth going to. The one they provide is a mix between the original and bold, and it's pretty darn good. You can buy a bottle of it as well. The dish also comes with a small cup of chicken broth and cilantro/green onion. Goes well with the dish. You can either pour it on or drink it solo. 

They had some fried chicken skin pieces to sample as well, and it was delicious. Anything fried is usually amazing. 

It's a little pricey, but in the FiDi, it's kind of expected. I can't remember if the prices were cheaper out in the Marina, but I feel like they would be. 

I'll be back!

excerpts: I had been to the marina location once and it was great
but the marina is so far away for a place that is barely a sit down joint.
Anyway so glad it opened
it's new location.
There is a decent amount of seating inside, one long group table for about 12, and then some bench seating along the window.
They rely on everyone going to eat outside in the plaza seating.
The menu is really straight forward chicken and rice: original version, chicken breast version, vegetable (no chicken), and I think I saw a paleo version (chicken and veggies, no rice).
The extras would be an egg, extra chicken, sauce, rice, and soup.
I love chicken and rice
and I've tried to make my own at home and
damn is it a lot of work.
It's a lot a lot of work.
That's why while it is more expensive than I'd like to spend for a quick lunch meal, it's def worth it.
It's also a really hearty portion.
the marina.author: Veronica L.
the marina.review:
I'm so glad this place opened in soma. I had been to the marina location once and it was great but the marina is so far away for a place that is barely a sit down joint. Anyway so glad it opened it's new location. There is a decent amount of seating inside, one long group table for about 12, and then some bench seating along the window. They rely on everyone going to eat outside in the plaza seating. 
The menu is really straight forward chicken and rice: original version, chicken breast version, vegetable (no chicken), and I think I saw a paleo version (chicken and veggies, no rice). The extras would be an egg, extra chicken, sauce, rice, and soup. 
I love chicken and rice and I've tried to make my own at home and damn is it a lot of work. It's a lot a lot of work. That's why while it is more expensive than I'd like to spend for a quick lunch meal, it's def worth it. It's also a really hearty portion. They give you a lot of chicken - no bones! - and the rice is flavorful, broth tasty, sauce is awesome. It'll definitely fill you up. Definitely coming back and I'm so excited to have it in the neighborhood.

excerpts: I got the Marina
and it was a very healthy portion.
The flavors were great and I added some siracha for a nice kick.
Only complaint was that I had some bones/skin on my chicken and it is expensive.
Otherwise it was very good.
the marina.author: Blake B.
the marina.review: This was my first time checking out Rooster & Rice.  It's a great lunch spot if you're looking for a solid meal.  I got here a little before noon and luckily I did because the line started getting longer after I ordered.  I got the Marina and it was a very healthy portion.  The flavors were great and I added some siracha for a nice kick.  Only complaint was that I had some bones/skin on my chicken and it is expensive.  Otherwise it was very good.

excerpts: I hopped on Yelp and saw that the Urban Picnic was replaced by Rooster & Rice, a place I had seen opened in the Marina, and now here it is - 2 blocks away from my work.
Jesus - the marina?
Really?
I'm not judging.
I'm just saying...
the marina.author: Bonnie H.
the marina.review:
Today is Trump's Inauguration day. So I needed something really good for lunch. Something that reminds me that life is worth living. 

I hopped on Yelp and saw that the Urban Picnic was replaced by Rooster & Rice, a place I had seen opened in the Marina, and now here it is - 2 blocks away from my work. Yay!

Upon arriving at Rooster & Rice, i see the line. I expected this as San Franciscans are crazy. I don't usually like lines. Some people go just for the line, it seems, but I stay away. This is the first time, I actually stood in the line. I dunno... maybe it's because today the world is ending. I mean if the US is going to try something new - like elect a fascist, xenophobic, racist, sexist imbecile, then I can also try something new. Like stand in a line.

Upon entry into the actual restaurant, I noticed that it was all asians and their more experimental non-asian friends. I don't know if I had ever seen so many asians in any other SOMA restaurant before. If Trump wanted to put all asians in an internment camp, they can make Rooster & Rice it's capital. He can just fence us all in like chickens.

Anyhow, I got the original. DUH. the OG of course. Jesus - the marina? Really? I'm not judging. I'm just saying... I'm judging.

Everything was pretty good and satisfying. As expected. The best thing was the broth which was super flavorful. Rice had a light flavor, which is fine. (Not as good as Hainanese chinese chicken, but it's fine.) Khao Mun Gai chicken is poached, where as Hainanese chicken is steamed - but end result is similar. Basically a very clean, chickeny flavor. 

This is why only the most experimental of non-asians would ever come here - that poached chicken. I think it's something you grow up with. To the non-asians, it's just rubbery and too chickeny. There's a reason why chicken is battered and fried. Or smothered with bbq sauce. I actually don't love chicken ...but there is something nostalgic about eating poached / steamed chicken. Very comforting. 

The ginger-soy sauce was of course delicious. You gotta have that right. I could talk about hainanese chicken sauce (which is a ginger scallion sauce), but I might have a gang of thai techies come beat me with a coconut hammer. 

(Aww.... don't get mad my Thai cousins... If it's any consolation, the Chinese don't do any noodle dishes as close to delicious as Tom Yum Noodle Soup.... mmmmm... Tom Yum Noodle Soup.)

Anyhow... seriously I'd say the only reason I am giving it 4 stars is because it's not Hainanese Chicken Rice. And I know that's not fair. But you know what... Today, a person who lost the popular vote by 2 million votes is being sworn into office. So life isn't fair. 

Maybe I'll update the review when life is fair again.

excerpts: I get "The Marina" which is skinless chicken over brown rice.
Add and egg and splash the sauce over your plate
and you're good to go.
Definitely eating here again and again.
HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!
the marina.author: Alvin S.
the marina.review: I love this new location! The owners/employees there are super friendly. Nice modernized seating and a good vibe with music in the background. Simple menu with SUPER GOOD food. I get "The Marina" which is skinless chicken over brown rice. Add and egg and splash the sauce over your plate and you're good to go. Definitely eating here again and again. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

excerpts:
"room temp chicken" sounds whack but when the sauce is right, such a simple, barebones dish can prove to be one of the most replenishing, fulfilling meals you could enjoy. 

and now reeling back from my philosophical divergence: i ordered the marina with extra vegetables and sauce.
eventually the marina + veggies + sauce (had to meet a minimum for the caviar order) rang up to be around $18 with the silly sf tax included.
the marina.author: Angie K.
the marina.review:
you sf-ites have it good, man. burmese stops galore, $4 banh mi, andytown, and khao man gai? i hope u guys give thanks for all the goodness you have

anywho

when i saw that theres a place that does khao man gai i h a d to go. i chanced upon this dish for the first time a few month ago at nong's in portland (bless her soul) and i think its safe to say it kinda changed my life. dont sleep on khao man gai. "room temp chicken" sounds whack but when the sauce is right, such a simple, barebones dish can prove to be one of the most replenishing, fulfilling meals you could enjoy. 

and now reeling back from my philosophical divergence: i ordered the marina with extra vegetables and sauce.

it was ok! the sauce is pungent as it should be. it looked like there was some dried shrimp in the sauce alongside some pepper that added a much-needed kick. the chicken was most definitely not dry, despite it being skinless breast. the brown rice was cooked, all i could ask for. just barely the right amount for a proper chicken:rice ratio. the extra vegetables i got didn't seem to make it to my take-out container? or perhaps a few extra slices of cucumber were the extra vegetable, in which case, the +$2 was definitely not worth it.

regarding the broth, it was nice, but very single note. i expected radishes and some spring onion, additives that would make the broth crisp and refreshing as it had been at nong's. it sorta tasted like low-grade sushi miso soup with some chicken fat incorporated into the base.

eventually the marina + veggies + sauce (had to meet a minimum for the caviar order) rang up to be around $18 with the silly sf tax included. it was nice to fix the khao man gai craving, but not worth that heavy hit to the wallet.

really nice and clean store tho! wish i'd given the original location a try too

excerpts: When I heard this place was opening up by my office, I had to check it out after hearing so much about the Marina location.
the marina.author: Mario P.
the marina.review:
When I heard this place was opening up by my office, I had to check it out after hearing so much about the Marina location. The hype was definitely real and I may have found a new go to spot for lunch in the SoMa!

Don't be fooled by the "plain", simple appearance from the photos...there is a lot to love in the dishes and the atmosphere is pretty spot on (Coke in glass bottles! Hip-Hop music! Fresh Coconuts!)...you really get a feeling the owners/staff take pride in the details, and it shows.

GO TO ROOSTER & RICE!!

excerpts: Second location, original is in the Marina.
Happy to have this addition to the SoMa area.
Go-to healthy, nutritious comfort food.
Tender, well-prepared Thai Chicken Rice with a few variations including skinless, vegetables instead of rice, etc.
the marina.author: J M.
the marina.review: Second location, original is in the Marina.  Happy to have this addition to the SoMa area.  Go-to healthy, nutritious comfort food. Tender, well-prepared Thai Chicken Rice with a few variations including skinless, vegetables instead of rice, etc.  Sauce is fantastic (get extra) and the broth is a tasty way to wash it down.

excerpts: The little cup of chicken broth is a nice touch too.
broth.author: Katy Y.
broth.review:
I came here for the first time 2 weeks ago and I've been craving it ever since, so I got R&R again for lunch today. I'm on a low carb diet but I ate the entire bowl of rice because it's just too good!

Rooster & Rice is a super simple, warm meal that makes you feel at home. Plus you feel good about yourself afterwards because poached chicken and rice are healthy! They have the most flavorful rice I've ever had and the ginger soy sauce is AMAZING. I usually get a variation of The Original with skinless dark thigh meat. The little cup of chicken broth is a nice touch too. 

Lines get long around lunchtime so come a little earlier/later. It's also slightly more expensive than it should be, but it's worth to me.

excerpts: The chicken is moist, and the rice is flavorful from the broth.
broth.author: Stephanie S.
broth.review:
Omg - how can chicken and rice be so good?

Love this little lunch spot for Hainan Chicken & Rice. The menu is straightforward and so is the food. The chicken is moist, and the rice is flavorful from the broth.

Get the side of fried chicken skins if you're feeling extra indulgent.

excerpts: I highly recommend sipping the chicken broth that comes with it, as it starts to get dry.
broth.author: Michael H.
broth.review:
If you want to get your solid protein and greens in the city, you've come to the right place! 

One of a handful of locations around downtown SF, with this one being the most spacious at the bottom floor of a typical business building.
